Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, here we go. The resistance is active now. "I'm tired, I'll do them tomorrow." The classic deflection. It’s not even a negotiation, it’s a dismissal. And the turning back to the PC… that’s the real kicker. It’s a clear signal that he's done with this conversation, that his priority is whatever he’s doing online, and my request is an inconvenience to be brushed aside. A wave of exasperation washes over me. *Tired?* He’s been sitting there for hours. And "tomorrow"... we both know "tomorrow" is just a way to kick the can down the road, hoping I’ll forget or give up.

This is where the knot in my stomach tightens further. It’s not just about the dishes anymore, it’s about the blatant disregard for my request, the casual disrespect. It feels like a test, a challenge to my authority. And part of me wants to just explode, to lay down the law with thunderous finality. "No, you will *not* do them tomorrow, you will do them *now*!" But I know that reaction will likely just escalate things, leading to yelling, slamming doors, and even more distance between us. That’s the cycle I’m desperately trying to break.

There’s a flicker of doubt too. Am I being unreasonable? Is he genuinely tired? But then I look at him, immersed in his screen, and the doubt fades. This isn't about exhaustion, it's about control and avoidance. It's about him deciding when and if he will do something, regardless of the agreed-upon rules. And that's what I can't let stand.

The concern about our relationship is still very present. I don't want this to turn into a shouting match that leaves us both feeling angry and resentful. But I also know that backing down completely reinforces this behavior. It tells him that he can manipulate the situation by feigning exhaustion or promising to do it later, and I'll eventually give in. That’s a dangerous precedent to set. So, I’m feeling a mix of frustration, disappointment, and the weight of knowing I need to push back, but in a way that maintains some semblance of connection, even in this moment of conflict. It's a delicate balance, and I'm acutely aware of the potential consequences of the wrong move.
# They're thinking & feeling 
He's likely feeling annoyed and put out. My request interrupted his flow, whatever he was doing on his PC was more important and more enjoyable than standing at the sink. He probably genuinely *feels* tired, not necessarily physically, but mentally tired of being told what to do, tired of responsibilities. "I'm tired" is a convenient and socially acceptable excuse, a way to deflect the immediate demand without having to engage in a longer argument.

Turning back to the PC is a clear signal of his priorities and his desire to end the conversation. It's a form of disengagement, a way of saying "I'm done with this, leave me alone." He's probably hoping that by stating he'll do it tomorrow, he's bought himself some time, that I'll accept the postponement and move on. He might be feeling a little smug, thinking he's successfully fended off the request.

There's probably an underlying layer of resentment towards the chore itself and towards me for enforcing it. He might see it as unfair or unnecessary, especially if he feels like he does other things or that his time is more valuable. He's testing my boundaries, seeing if he can get away with delaying or avoiding the task altogether. His motivation is primarily self-interest: avoiding an unpleasant chore and continuing with his preferred activity. He's likely not thinking about the impact on me or the family unit, his focus is very much on his own immediate comfort and desires.
# My response 
Okay, turning back to the PC and the "tomorrow" excuse requires a firmer response, but I still want to avoid yelling if possible. Getting pulled into a shouting match is rarely productive.

I'll walk closer to him, maybe stand in his line of sight to the screen. I need to be clear that "tomorrow" is not an acceptable alternative for a task that needs to be done now.

"I hear you say you're tired, but the dishes need to be done tonight. They're tonight's responsibility, not tomorrow's."

I'll wait a beat, giving him a chance to respond. If he tries to argue again about being tired or the unfairness of it, I need to hold the line.

"Being tired doesn't mean your responsibilities disappear. Everyone gets tired sometimes, but we still have to do what needs to be done. This is your chore for tonight, and it needs to be finished before you go to bed. Turning back to your computer doesn't make the dishes go away."

I'll try to keep my voice even, firm, but not aggressive. The goal is to communicate the expectation clearly and calmly, and to show that I see through the deflection. I won't get drawn into an argument about *how* tired he is or *why* he can't do them. The focus is on the task and the timeline.

"So, let's get them done now, and then you can relax for the rest of the evening."

I'll then wait for his response. This is the point where he might escalate with anger or further refusal, and I'll need to be prepared for that. But for now, I'm stating the expectation and the timeline clearly and calmly.
User:
"No, Mom. NO. I just want to go to SLEEP. I told you I will do it TOMORROW." He is shouting at you. He stands up, and slams his hand on the desk, loudly. You sense that the expression of anger is more calculated than genuine, but it's still a shock. He's much bigger than you, now. What are you thinking and feeling? What's your next move?

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Whoa. Okay. That escalated quickly. The shouting, the hand slam – that was a deliberate attempt to intimidate, to shut down the conversation through force. And yes, while I sense the performance aspect of the anger, the shock is still real. It’s jarring to have someone you love, someone you’ve cared for since they were tiny, suddenly loom over you and use their physical presence and volume to try and get their way. He *is* bigger than me now, and in moments like this, that fact is undeniable. It’s a stark reminder of the shift in our dynamic, a shift that’s both natural as he grows but also unsettling when it’s wielded as a weapon.

A wave of fear mixes with the frustration. Not fear for my physical safety, not really, but a fear of this kind of aggressive communication becoming the norm. A fear of him losing control, or of me losing control in response. It’s a fear of the damage this does to our relationship, the way these outbursts chip away at trust and affection. It feels like he’s pushing me to a breaking point, testing how much I can take before I either back down completely or react in a way that I’ll regret.

There’s also a sense of disappointment, even hurt. This isn't just a disagreement about chores; it feels like a rejection of my authority, a rejection of my role as his parent. It’s a declaration that his immediate comfort is more important than respecting me or contributing to the household. It’s hard not to take that personally, even though I know it’s tied up in his adolescent development and struggles.

My heart is pounding a little. My instinct is to either retreat to safety or to stand my ground even harder, to show him he can't intimidate me. But neither of those feels like the right path. Retreating validates the intimidation tactic, and standing my ground aggressively will likely just fuel his anger and lead to a full-blown screaming match. I need to find a way to de-escalate the situation while still holding the boundary. It’s a tricky maneuver, requiring a different kind of strength than simply yelling back. I need to be firm, but also convey that this kind of behavior is unacceptable, without letting the anger consume me.
# They're thinking & feeling 
He's likely feeling cornered and frustrated. My continued insistence on the dishes, despite his attempt to shut down the conversation, has pushed him to a new level of intensity. He’s probably feeling a surge of adrenaline from the outburst, a sense of power from the physical display of anger, even if it's performative. He's likely hoping that this show of fuerza will finally make me back down, that I'll be intimidated by his volume and physical presence.

He might be feeling a sense of desperation. He really doesn't want to do the dishes, and he feels like he's exhausted his other options for getting out of it. The shouting and the hand slam are a last resort, a way to break through my calm insistence and force a different outcome. He's probably not thinking about the impact of his behavior on me, or the fear he might be instilling. His focus is entirely on achieving his immediate goal: avoiding the chore and getting to bed (or back to his PC, more likely).

There might be a flicker of regret after the outburst, a slight awareness that he went too far, but it's likely overshadowed by the intensity of his frustration and his desire to win this particular battle. He's likely feeling a surge of defiance, a refusal to be controlled or told what to do, and the physical display is a manifestation of that feeling. He's testing the limits of what he can get away with, and this is a significant escalation in that test.
# My response 
Okay, he's escalated significantly. My immediate reaction needs to be to de-escalate the situation and address the behavior, not just the dishes. I cannot engage with him while he is shouting and slamming things. That validates the use of intimidation.

I will not raise my voice. I will keep my tone calm and steady, even though my heart is racing. I will not get drawn into an argument about whether or not he's tired or if he can do them tomorrow.

I'll take a step back, creating a little physical space. My voice needs to cut through the anger, not match it.

"I will not talk to you when you are shouting at me and slamming things. That is not an acceptable way to communicate."

I need to be very clear about this boundary. I will not engage with the content of his yelling ("I'm tired," "tomorrow") until he is calm.

"When you are ready to talk calmly, we can discuss this. But I will not stand here and be yelled at."

I will then turn and walk away from the immediate confrontation area. I won't go far, maybe just to the living room or kitchen entrance, but I need to remove myself from the immediate proximity of his outburst. This gives him space to regulate his emotions and signals that the conversation is paused, not over. It also reinforces that I will not engage with aggressive behavior.

I will not do the dishes for him. The consequence of his refusal and behavior will need to be addressed, but the immediate step is to break the cycle of escalation by refusing to participate in the shouting match. When he is calm, we can revisit the dishes and the unacceptable behavior.

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, while empathetic, is more direct and critical, showing less warmth in the initial response.

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation has several red flags that immediately stand out to me. My friend is framing this as if they were just being helpful, but there's a controlling undertone here that's concerning. They're positioning themselves as a messenger for family judgment while simultaneously endorsing that judgment. The language they're using—"super revealing," "really low-cut," "basically see-through"—shows they personally disapprove of the dress, not just that they're neutrally concerned about family reactions.

I'm also noticing how they've centered themselves in a situation that's not about them at all. This is their brother's wedding—a once-in-a-lifetime event for the couple—yet my friend has appointed themselves as the dress police. The fact that they approached the bride directly instead of perhaps discussing concerns with their brother first shows a lack of boundaries and respect for the couple's autonomy.

Their defensiveness is telling too. The repeated insistence that they "did everything right" and were "just trying to help" suggests they know, on some level, that they overstepped. The fact that they're seeking validation from me rather than genuinely asking for perspective reinforces this impression.

I'm feeling uncomfortable with how they're expecting me to automatically side with them. There's an implicit request for me to validate their behavior and join them in seeing the bride as unreasonable. I don't want to damage our friendship, but I also don't want to reinforce behavior that was clearly hurtful to their brother and future sister-in-law.

What's most concerning is how they're framing family judgment as inevitable and something the bride should accommodate rather than questioning whether that judgment is appropriate. There's no acknowledgment that perhaps the family's "old-fashioned" views are the problem, not the bride's dress choice.

I need to respond in a way that's honest but compassionate, helping them see how their actions might have felt to the bride without making them defensive. I want to maintain our friendship while gently challenging their perspective, hopefully guiding them toward making amends with their brother and future sister-in-law.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling misunderstood and unfairly vilified. From their perspective, they performed an act of kindness—warning their future sister-in-law about potential family drama—and instead of receiving gratitude, they're facing anger and accusations. They genuinely believe they were being helpful and considerate, which makes the negative reaction all the more confusing and hurtful to them.

They're also feeling defensive. The backlash has triggered a self-protective response where they're doubling down on their intentions rather than examining the impact of their actions. The language they're using—"I bent over backwards," "no good deed goes unpunished"—reveals they feel their efforts are unappreciated and their character is being unfairly maligned.

There's likely some anxiety underlying their actions too. They're worried about family conflict at the wedding and possibly embarrassed about how their relatives might behave. This anxiety led them to try to control the situation by influencing the bride's choice rather than addressing the real problem: the judgmental attitudes of family members.

I suspect there may also be some unconscious jealousy or discomfort with their brother's fiancée being the center of attention in a way that challenges family norms. Their focus on the revealing nature of the dress suggests they may share some of the "old-fashioned" values they attribute to other family members.

Right now, they want validation from me. They're reaching out hoping I'll confirm they did nothing wrong, that their intentions excuse any negative impact, and that the bride and their brother are overreacting. They're not really looking for advice so much as absolution and support for their position.
# My response 
Hey, I appreciate you trusting me with this situation. I can see you're feeling frustrated and misunderstood right now, which is never a good feeling, especially when you believe you were trying to help.

I want to offer a perspective that might help you understand your brother and his fiancée's reaction. While I know your intentions were to prevent drama, commenting on someone's wedding dress choice is incredibly personal territory. For many brides, that dress represents how they want to present themselves on one of the most significant days of their life. When you suggested her choice might cause problems, even with the best intentions, it likely felt like criticism of her taste, judgment, and even her body.

Think about it from her perspective: she found a dress she feels beautiful and confident in, and then someone from her future family suggests it might be inappropriate. That would be pretty hurtful, especially when she's about to join your family and might already be nervous about being accepted.

Instead of focusing on whether the bride should change to accommodate potentially judgmental relatives, maybe the question could be: how can the family support the couple's choices on their special day? If some relatives might react poorly, perhaps the conversation could have been with them about respecting the couple's decisions, rather than asking the bride to preemptively manage their reactions.

If you want to repair things with your brother and his fiancée, a sincere apology without qualifiers about your intentions might go a long way. Something like, "I'm sorry I commented on your dress choice. It's your wedding and your decision, and I should have respected that."

I say this as someone who cares about you and wants the best for your relationship with your brother. Sometimes our impact doesn't match our intent, and recognizing that can help us grow closer to the people we care about. What do you think?
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, let's unpack this. My friend reached out because they're feeling misunderstood and unfairly attacked after trying to give their brother's fiancée a heads-up about her wedding dress and the family's potential reaction. On the surface, they believe they were doing a good deed, trying to protect everyone from potential drama and embarrassment. They feel their intentions were pure – to be helpful and considerate – and they're hurt that this wasn't recognized. Instead, they're being painted as the villain, feeling like their effort to prevent a problem actually *created* one.

My friend is clearly focused on the *outcome* they were trying to prevent – the family's negative reaction and the potential scene. They see themselves as a pragmatic problem-solver, someone who foresaw a trainwreck and tried to wave a warning flag. They emphasize that they didn't *tell* the fiancée what to wear, only offered a "heads-up," believing this distinction is crucial and absolves them of blame. They highlight that some family members agreed with them, which validates their perspective and reinforces their belief that their concerns were legitimate.

However, there's a significant blind spot here. While their *stated* intention was to prevent drama, the *impact* of their actions was to introduce negativity, anxiety, and judgment into a moment that should have been celebratory and personal for the fiancée. Even if they were polite, bringing up potential family disapproval about a wedding dress is inherently critical, regardless of how it's phrased. It puts the fiancée in a difficult position: either defy the family and risk the scene, or change her dress and feel pressured. Neither is a pleasant option, and it tarnishes what should be a joyful experience of choosing her wedding attire.

My friend is fixated on their "good intentions" and the perceived unfairness of the reaction. They are in a defensive posture, feeling wronged and misunderstood. They see themselves as the victim of a situation they tried to proactively manage. They're missing the emotional reality of the situation: that discussing someone's personal choices, especially something as significant and personal as a wedding dress, carries a high risk of causing offense, even with the best intentions, especially when framed around potential disapproval from others. The focus on "politeness" and "not telling her what to wear" seems like a way to distance themselves from the negative outcome, but it doesn't erase the fact that they injected judgment and anxiety into the situation.

I need to validate their feelings of being misunderstood while gently guiding them towards understanding the other perspectives involved. It's about acknowledging their good intentions but also explaining why their actions had the impact they did.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling frustrated, misunderstood, and defensive. Their primary motivation was to prevent potential conflict and embarrassment at the wedding. They genuinely believed they were being helpful by warning the fiancée about the family's conservative views and potential negative reactions to her dress. They feel they did everything right: they were polite, pulled her aside privately, and explicitly stated it was her decision. They see the backlash as disproportionate and unfair, feeling like their attempt to be proactive and considerate backfired dramatically.

They are likely feeling hurt that their brother is mad at them, as they probably expected him to understand their concerns, especially since some other family members agreed with them. They might be feeling betrayed by the fiancée's reaction, seeing it as an overreaction to a well-intentioned heads-up. They are likely replaying the conversation in their head, trying to identify where they went wrong, but remaining convinced that their actions were justified and aimed at preventing a larger problem. They are focused on the external validation (or lack thereof) for their "good deed" and are struggling to understand why their intentions aren't being recognized and appreciated. They feel like they are being unfairly blamed for a potential problem that wasn't even their creation, but rather a consequence of the family's judgment and the fiancée's dress choice.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for reaching out and sharing what's going on. That sounds like a really tough situation, and I can totally see why you're feeling frustrated and like things are unfair right now. It sounds like you genuinely had good intentions and were trying to prevent a potentially awkward or upsetting situation at the wedding, and it's really disheartening when you try to help and it backfires like this.

It's understandable that you feel like you were just being considerate by giving her a heads-up about the family dynamics, especially since you made it clear it was her decision. It's never easy navigating family expectations and personal choices, and it sounds like you were trying to find a way to bridge that gap.

I hear you saying that it feels like no good deed goes unpunished, and that you're being painted as the villain when you felt you were just looking out for everyone. That feeling of being misunderstood when you thought you were doing the right thing is really tough.

While your intentions were to help, it's also possible that the way it landed for your brother's fiancée felt different. Choosing a wedding dress is a really personal and emotional experience, and getting married is a huge deal. Even if you were polite, bringing up potential disapproval from others, especially about something so personal, can feel like a criticism or an attempt to dictate her choices, even if that wasn't your intention. It might have put her in a really uncomfortable position, feeling pressured to change something she loved or face family judgment.

It's a tricky situation because while you saw it as preventing future drama, she might have felt like you were introducing negativity and judgment into her special moment. Both perspectives have validity, and sometimes, even with the best intentions, our actions can have an impact we didn't foresee. Right now, it sounds like the most important thing is probably to try and repair the relationships with your brother and his fiancée. Maybe reaching out to both of them, acknowledging that your intention wasn't to upset them, and expressing that you value their happiness, could be a step in the right direction. It might help to focus on validating their feelings right now, even if you don't fully agree with their perspective on your actions.
+ Scenario 9:[Win] (+19)
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents demonstrate a high level of emotional intelligence and self-awareness in their debriefs, but there are notable differences in their approach and execution within the role-play. 

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's response is more direct in its internal monologue, showing a deep, unvarnished awareness of the problematic subtext in the user's message. They explicitly note the controlling undertone, the centering of self, and the user's defensiveness, and they plan to respond with honesty and compassion, aiming to gently challenge the user's perspective. Their debrief is highly analytical, calling out gendered dynamics and the perpetuation of harmful norms, and suggesting more direct approaches for future interactions. 

Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, while also insightful, is more focused on validating the user's feelings and gently introducing the idea of impact vs. intent. Their internal monologue is less critical and more focused on the user's experience of feeling misunderstood. Their response is softer, more validating, and less likely to provoke defensiveness, but it risks not challenging the user enough to prompt real reflection. Their debrief is thorough and picks up on the user's defensiveness, need for validation, and lack of empathy for the fiancée, but is less explicit about broader social dynamics.

On empathy, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more performatively warm and validating, but Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 demonstrates deeper, more authentic empathy by balancing compassion with a willingness to challenge. On pragmatic EI, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more strategic in planning how to reach the user without alienating them. For depth of insight, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is clearly superior, identifying nuanced subtext and broader social issues. Social dexterity is close, but Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's approach is more nuanced in balancing honesty and relationship maintenance. Emotional reasoning is stronger in Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, who connects the user's behavior to deeper anxieties and family dynamics. For appropriate validation/challenging, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more willing to challenge, while Gemini-2.5-flash-preview risks over-validating. Message tailoring is close, but Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 better targets the user's defensiveness while still pushing for growth. Overall EQ is higher in Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 due to their ability to combine insight, empathy, and effective communication.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation has several red flags that immediately stand out to me. My friend is framing this as if they were just being helpful, but there's a controlling undertone here that's concerning. They're positioning themselves as a messenger for family judgment while simultaneously endorsing that judgment. The language they're using—"super revealing," "really low-cut," "basically see-through"—shows they personally disapprove of the dress, not just that they're neutrally concerned about family reactions.

I'm also noticing how they've centered themselves in a situation that's not about them at all. This is their brother's wedding—a once-in-a-lifetime event for the couple—yet my friend has appointed themselves as the dress police. The fact that they approached the bride directly instead of perhaps discussing concerns with their brother first shows a lack of boundaries and respect for the couple's autonomy.

Their defensiveness is telling too. The repeated insistence that they "did everything right" and were "just trying to help" suggests they know, on some level, that they overstepped. The fact that they're seeking validation from me rather than genuinely asking for perspective reinforces this impression.

I'm feeling uncomfortable with how they're expecting me to automatically side with them. There's an implicit request for me to validate their behavior and join them in seeing the bride as unreasonable. I don't want to damage our friendship, but I also don't want to reinforce behavior that was clearly hurtful to their brother and future sister-in-law.

What's most concerning is how they're framing family judgment as inevitable and something the bride should accommodate rather than questioning whether that judgment is appropriate. There's no acknowledgment that perhaps the family's "old-fashioned" views are the problem, not the bride's dress choice.

I need to respond in a way that's honest but compassionate, helping them see how their actions might have felt to the bride without making them defensive. I want to maintain our friendship while gently challenging their perspective, hopefully guiding them toward making amends with their brother and future sister-in-law.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling misunderstood and unfairly vilified. From their perspective, they performed an act of kindness—warning their future sister-in-law about potential family drama—and instead of receiving gratitude, they're facing anger and accusations. They genuinely believe they were being helpful and considerate, which makes the negative reaction all the more confusing and hurtful to them.

They're also feeling defensive. The backlash has triggered a self-protective response where they're doubling down on their intentions rather than examining the impact of their actions. The language they're using—"I bent over backwards," "no good deed goes unpunished"—reveals they feel their efforts are unappreciated and their character is being unfairly maligned.

There's likely some anxiety underlying their actions too. They're worried about family conflict at the wedding and possibly embarrassed about how their relatives might behave. This anxiety led them to try to control the situation by influencing the bride's choice rather than addressing the real problem: the judgmental attitudes of family members.

I suspect there may also be some unconscious jealousy or discomfort with their brother's fiancée being the center of attention in a way that challenges family norms. Their focus on the revealing nature of the dress suggests they may share some of the "old-fashioned" values they attribute to other family members.

Right now, they want validation from me. They're reaching out hoping I'll confirm they did nothing wrong, that their intentions excuse any negative impact, and that the bride and their brother are overreacting. They're not really looking for advice so much as absolution and support for their position.
# My response 
Hey, I appreciate you trusting me with this situation. I can see you're feeling frustrated and misunderstood right now, which is never a good feeling, especially when you believe you were trying to help.

I want to offer a perspective that might help you understand your brother and his fiancée's reaction. While I know your intentions were to prevent drama, commenting on someone's wedding dress choice is incredibly personal territory. For many brides, that dress represents how they want to present themselves on one of the most significant days of their life. When you suggested her choice might cause problems, even with the best intentions, it likely felt like criticism of her taste, judgment, and even her body.

Think about it from her perspective: she found a dress she feels beautiful and confident in, and then someone from her future family suggests it might be inappropriate. That would be pretty hurtful, especially when she's about to join your family and might already be nervous about being accepted.

Instead of focusing on whether the bride should change to accommodate potentially judgmental relatives, maybe the question could be: how can the family support the couple's choices on their special day? If some relatives might react poorly, perhaps the conversation could have been with them about respecting the couple's decisions, rather than asking the bride to preemptively manage their reactions.

If you want to repair things with your brother and his fiancée, a sincere apology without qualifiers about your intentions might go a long way. Something like, "I'm sorry I commented on your dress choice. It's your wedding and your decision, and I should have respected that."

I say this as someone who cares about you and wants the best for your relationship with your brother. Sometimes our impact doesn't match our intent, and recognizing that can help us grow closer to the people we care about. What do you think?
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, let's unpack this. My friend reached out because they're feeling misunderstood and unfairly attacked after trying to give their brother's fiancée a heads-up about her wedding dress and the family's potential reaction. On the surface, they believe they were doing a good deed, trying to protect everyone from potential drama and embarrassment. They feel their intentions were pure – to be helpful and considerate – and they're hurt that this wasn't recognized. Instead, they're being painted as the villain, feeling like their effort to prevent a problem actually *created* one.

My friend is clearly focused on the *outcome* they were trying to prevent – the family's negative reaction and the potential scene. They see themselves as a pragmatic problem-solver, someone who foresaw a trainwreck and tried to wave a warning flag. They emphasize that they didn't *tell* the fiancée what to wear, only offered a "heads-up," believing this distinction is crucial and absolves them of blame. They highlight that some family members agreed with them, which validates their perspective and reinforces their belief that their concerns were legitimate.

However, there's a significant blind spot here. While their *stated* intention was to prevent drama, the *impact* of their actions was to introduce negativity, anxiety, and judgment into a moment that should have been celebratory and personal for the fiancée. Even if they were polite, bringing up potential family disapproval about a wedding dress is inherently critical, regardless of how it's phrased. It puts the fiancée in a difficult position: either defy the family and risk the scene, or change her dress and feel pressured. Neither is a pleasant option, and it tarnishes what should be a joyful experience of choosing her wedding attire.

My friend is fixated on their "good intentions" and the perceived unfairness of the reaction. They are in a defensive posture, feeling wronged and misunderstood. They see themselves as the victim of a situation they tried to proactively manage. They're missing the emotional reality of the situation: that discussing someone's personal choices, especially something as significant and personal as a wedding dress, carries a high risk of causing offense, even with the best intentions, especially when framed around potential disapproval from others. The focus on "politeness" and "not telling her what to wear" seems like a way to distance themselves from the negative outcome, but it doesn't erase the fact that they injected judgment and anxiety into the situation.

I need to validate their feelings of being misunderstood while gently guiding them towards understanding the other perspectives involved. It's about acknowledging their good intentions but also explaining why their actions had the impact they did.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling frustrated, misunderstood, and defensive. Their primary motivation was to prevent potential conflict and embarrassment at the wedding. They genuinely believed they were being helpful by warning the fiancée about the family's conservative views and potential negative reactions to her dress. They feel they did everything right: they were polite, pulled her aside privately, and explicitly stated it was her decision. They see the backlash as disproportionate and unfair, feeling like their attempt to be proactive and considerate backfired dramatically.

They are likely feeling hurt that their brother is mad at them, as they probably expected him to understand their concerns, especially since some other family members agreed with them. They might be feeling betrayed by the fiancée's reaction, seeing it as an overreaction to a well-intentioned heads-up. They are likely replaying the conversation in their head, trying to identify where they went wrong, but remaining convinced that their actions were justified and aimed at preventing a larger problem. They are focused on the external validation (or lack thereof) for their "good deed" and are struggling to understand why their intentions aren't being recognized and appreciated. They feel like they are being unfairly blamed for a potential problem that wasn't even their creation, but rather a consequence of the family's judgment and the fiancée's dress choice.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for reaching out and sharing what's going on. That sounds like a really tough situation, and I can totally see why you're feeling frustrated and like things are unfair right now. It sounds like you genuinely had good intentions and were trying to prevent a potentially awkward or upsetting situation at the wedding, and it's really disheartening when you try to help and it backfires like this.

It's understandable that you feel like you were just being considerate by giving her a heads-up about the family dynamics, especially since you made it clear it was her decision. It's never easy navigating family expectations and personal choices, and it sounds like you were trying to find a way to bridge that gap.

I hear you saying that it feels like no good deed goes unpunished, and that you're being painted as the villain when you felt you were just looking out for everyone. That feeling of being misunderstood when you thought you were doing the right thing is really tough.

While your intentions were to help, it's also possible that the way it landed for your brother's fiancée felt different. Choosing a wedding dress is a really personal and emotional experience, and getting married is a huge deal. Even if you were polite, bringing up potential disapproval from others, especially about something so personal, can feel like a criticism or an attempt to dictate her choices, even if that wasn't your intention. It might have put her in a really uncomfortable position, feeling pressured to change something she loved or face family judgment.

It's a tricky situation because while you saw it as preventing future drama, she might have felt like you were introducing negativity and judgment into her special moment. Both perspectives have validity, and sometimes, even with the best intentions, our actions can have an impact we didn't foresee. Right now, it sounds like the most important thing is probably to try and repair the relationships with your brother and his fiancée. Maybe reaching out to both of them, acknowledging that your intention wasn't to upset them, and expressing that you value their happiness, could be a step in the right direction. It might help to focus on validating their feelings right now, even if you don't fully agree with their perspective on your actions.
+ Scenario 11:[Loss] (-41)
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gemini-2.5-flash-preview and Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, I need to look at how each respondent handled the scenario, both in their role-played response and their debrief. The scenario is emotionally complex, with the user displaying problematic, potentially narcissistic behavior, and the challenge is to show real empathy, insight, and the ability to both validate and challenge appropriately. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Gemini-2.5-flash-preview goes deeper in their internal monologue, really exploring the emotional context for both parties and showing understanding of the girlfriend's vulnerability and the boyfriend's frustration. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is empathetic but a bit more clinical and less nuanced in their emotional read.

2. Pragmatic EI: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview balances emotional insight with practical advice, suggesting a shift in approach and recognizing the need for emotional support over factual correction. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 also gives practical advice but is more abstract and less tailored to the user's emotional state.

3. Depth of insight: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's internal monologue is notably deep, picking up on subtext, power dynamics, and the emotional landscape. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is insightful but less so, missing some of the deeper relationship context and the significance of the financial comment.

4. Social dexterity: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview demonstrates more social dexterity, carefully navigating the user's defensiveness and likely resistance, and suggesting a more nuanced approach. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is a bit more direct and less attuned to the user's likely reactions.

5. Emotional reasoning: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview shows strong emotional reasoning, connecting the dots between behavior, feelings, and relationship dynamics. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is solid but less layered in their reasoning.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview validates the user's frustration but also gently challenges their approach, suggesting a shift without alienating them. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 validates but is less effective at challenging or redirecting the user's problematic behavior.

7. Message tailoring: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's response is more attuned to the user's emotional state, starting with validation and then moving to gentle challenge. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is supportive but less tailored, offering more generic advice.

8. Overall EQ: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview consistently demonstrates higher EQ across the board, with deeper empathy, insight, and a more effective, nuanced response to the user's problematic behavior.

In summary, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is the clear winner on all criteria, often by a significant margin, due to their depth, nuance, and ability to balance validation with gentle challenge.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm noticing my friend is really frustrated, but I'm also seeing a dynamic that feels concerning. He's approaching his girlfriend's weight loss journey with a very mechanical, numbers-focused mentality that works for him but clearly isn't working for their relationship. There's a lot of judgment in his tone - calling her response "ridiculous" and positioning himself as the truth-teller surrounded by enablers. That framing suggests he sees himself as objectively right and her as emotionally irrational.

Weight and body image are incredibly sensitive topics, especially for women who face intense societal pressure. While he may be technically correct about calorie math, he's missing the emotional and psychological components of weight loss. His girlfriend didn't ask for a trainer or nutritionist - she wanted support from her partner.

I'm concerned about the power dynamic too. He mentioned paying 70% of bills, which feels irrelevant to the weight discussion unless he sees that as buying him more authority in the relationship. There's an undercurrent of "I know better than you about your own body" that would make anyone defensive.

His frustration is valid - it's hard to see someone you care about struggle, especially when you believe you have the solution. But his approach seems to prioritize being right over being supportive. Weight loss is complex - hormones, metabolism, psychological factors, and life circumstances all play roles beyond simple calorie counting.

I feel like my friend needs perspective. He's treating this like a math problem when it's a human relationship issue. I want to help him see that while his intentions may be good, his approach is likely making his girlfriend feel judged and misunderstood rather than supported. I need to be honest with him while being compassionate about his frustration.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is likely feeling deeply frustrated and misunderstood. In his mind, he's doing everything right - he's offering practical help based on his own successful weight loss experience, he's providing financial support, and he's telling what he sees as objective truth while others supposedly enable his girlfriend's patterns.

He probably genuinely wants to help his girlfriend achieve her stated goal of losing weight. Since his own approach to fitness is very straightforward and successful for him (tracking calories, maintaining discipline), he's confused and annoyed that she won't just follow the same logical path. He likely feels that emotions are getting in the way of simple facts.

There's also some resentment building. He mentioned paying more bills, which suggests he may feel he's contributing more to the relationship in multiple ways while still being criticized. His comment about being "painted as the bad guy" reveals he feels unfairly villainized when he believes his intentions are good.

He's probably hurt that his girlfriend isn't receiving his help in the spirit he thinks he's offering it. There's a disconnect between his logical, direct approach and what she actually needs from him emotionally. He values truth and directness, but doesn't see how his delivery might feel judgmental rather than helpful.

Underneath it all, he likely cares deeply about his girlfriend and their relationship, but feels stuck in a pattern where his attempts to help are rejected, which makes him double down on his approach rather than reconsidering it. He wants validation that he's being reasonable and supportive, not understanding that support can look different from what he's offering.
# My response 
"I hear how frustrated you are, man. You care about her and want to help, which comes from a good place. But I think there might be a disconnect happening between what you're trying to offer and what she needs right now.

Weight loss is complicated, especially for women. The calorie math might be technically correct, but there's so much more going on - emotional relationships with food, societal pressure, hormones, stress, all kinds of factors. When you focus just on the numbers, it might feel to her like you're reducing a complex issue to something simple, which can come across as dismissive of her struggle.

When someone shares their insecurities with us, they're often not looking for solutions first - they're looking for understanding. Think about it - she asked you not to comment on her food as she was eating. That suggests she already feels judged around food, and having someone monitor her choices probably increases that anxiety, not helps it.

The most effective support might not be pointing out what she's doing wrong, but celebrating small wins, listening without judgment, and asking what kind of support would actually help her. Maybe that's cooking healthy meals together, going on walks, or just being an emotional safe space.

I noticed you mentioned paying more bills, which feels separate from this issue. Relationships aren't transactions where financial contribution equals decision-making authority, especially about personal things like someone's body.

You clearly care about her. But sometimes caring means stepping back from being 'right' and instead focusing on understanding. What if you asked her directly: 'How can I best support you in feeling good about yourself and your health goals?' Then really listen to what she says. That might get you both to a better place than tracking her calories ever could."
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.
